awd_titl_txt: An EEG investigation of temporal orienting of attention for goal-directed eye and hand movements
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Joo-Hyun Song at Brown University, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating the mechanisms of temporal orienting of attention in goal-directed eye and hand movements. Using temporal regularities in the environment, we can orient attention to specific points in time to select and prioritize an upcoming relevant event. This ability, called temporal orienting, can then facilitate upcoming perception and action in many everyday situations such as estimating the duration of a yellow traffic light when driving, approximating when to swing at a tennis ball, or deciding when to jump into a conversation. Research on temporal orienting has mostly focused on perception, uncovering the neural mechanisms by which temporal orienting modulates perception and its behavioral and neural consequences. While temporal orienting may be especially important for action; much is still unknown about its effects on action. How may temporal orienting contribute to the temporally precise planning and execution of actions such as goal-directed saccades and reaches? Do the effects of temporal orienting on eye and hand movements rely on distinct or overlapping neural mechanisms? This project aims to answer these questions and thereby uncover the principles about the interplay between time perception, attention, and action. The outcomes of the project have potential technological and clinical implications; they can inform brain-computer interface technology developed for motor control, effective information processing methods and interface design used in domains such as aviation and automotive industry, as well as rehabilitation programs used for neurological disorders involving motor control and timing deficits.
 
This project investigates the neural mechanisms by which temporal orienting of attention influences goal-directed saccades and reaches using eye- and hand-tracking combined with electroencephalography (EEG). Specifically, this project aims to reveal the motor effector-general and/or effector-specific influences of temporal orienting on ocular and manual motor control by testing the hypothesis that temporal orienting contributes to the temporally precise control of eye and hand movements by exerting its effects at a global level of motor control followed by effector-specific level of motor control. The effects of temporal orienting generated by different temporal structures such goal-driven temporal expectation (using probabilistic variations in target timing) and stimulus-driven temporal priming (using sequential repetitions versus switches in target timing) are considered to gain a more complete picture. By using multiple EEG data analysis methods to extract as much information as possible from the multidimensional EEG signals, and reinforcing exploratory analyses by replication, this project has the potential to provide a comprehensive understanding of the neural mechanisms of goal-directed eye and hand movements as well as how temporal orienting generated by various temporal structures provides anticipatory signals that modulate motor control. Overall, the outcomes of the project will contribute to a more unified framework for attention and action.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Having prior knowledge of movement parameters is important to optimize goal-directed action. Here, we studied how prior knowledge about the timing and direction of hand and eye movements shaped behavior and its neural underpinnings. We recorded EEG while participants performed a task in which they made quick hand movements (left or right keypress) or eye movements (leftward or rightward rapid eye movement toward a target on the screen) in response to a briefly presented left- or right-pointing arrow in the center of the screen. Participants experienced trials in which they could or couldn't predict the onset timing and/or the direction of the arrow in advance. In other words, on some trials, they could prepare the timing and/or direction of their responses in advance. We were interested in how the response speed and the neural correlates of motor preparation and visual attention differed between trials in which participants could and couldn't prepare their movement parameters in advance, separately for the hand and eye movement tasks.

Behavioral results revealed that prior knowledge about timing and direction speeded responses on their own and also potentiated the effect of each other such that prior knowledge about timing increased the effect of prior knowledge of direction and vice versa. The pattern of results was the same in the hand movement task and eye movement task suggesting that both motor systems had similar benefits at the behavioral level. EEG results revealed that, at the neural level, prior knowledge about the timing and direction had similar and distinct effects on hand and eye movement preparation. First, the ERP analyses revealed a common correlate of hand and eye movement preparation that was modulated by prior knowledge of movement parameters. A negative going slow-wave ERP component measured over the frontocentral sites indexing anticipatory processes (the Contingent Negative Variation, the "CNV"), reflected both the effects of timing and direction, observed both in the hand movement and eye movement task. This suggests that prior knowledge of the timing and direction of goal-directed movements is represented at a level of movement preparation that is independent of the specific effector used (shared between hand and eye). In the hand movement experiment, we also observed a distinction between the effects of timing and direction such that prior knowledge about direction was uniquely associated with greater lateralization well before the execution of the hand movement (the prestimulus Lateralized Readiness Potential, the "LRP"), which was not modulated by timing knowledge. Second, the time-frequency analyses revealed distinct correlates of hand and eye movement preparation that were modulated by prior knowledge about the timing and direction of movements. For instance, in the hand movement experiment, the effects were predominantly associated with a greater alpha and beta power decrease over the central sites associated with manual response preparation and execution. Similar to the ERP findings, we observed a distinction between the effects of timing and direction such that prior knowledge about direction was uniquely associated with a greater lateralized alpha and beta power decrease. However, this lateralized movement preparation was not modulated by timing knowledge. In the eye movement experiment, the effects were predominantly associated with a greater alpha power decrease over the posterior sites associated with visual processing and attention. This pattern of results suggests that prior knowledge of the timing and direction of goal-directed movements is also represented at a level of movement preparation that is specific to the effector used (distinct for hand and eye).

Overall, these results show that prior knowledge about movement parameters, in particular timing and direction, speeded responses similarly for hand and eye movements. However, the comparable behavioral outcomes were accompanied by both common and distinct neural modulations. This suggests that hand and eye movement preparation rely on both common (effector-general) and distinct  (effector-specific) neural mechanisms. The results of the research supported by this award have been shared with the research community at academic conferences and are being prepared for publication. The data will be shared with the broader research community upon publication. In addition to the scientific contributions summarized above, this award supported the training of the PI (Dr. Melisa Menceloglu). Dr. Menceloglu received training in skills and techniques to help further her research career (e.g., training in continuous hand and eye tracking methods and training in advanced EEG analysis methods) and conducted additional research in perception and action. Dr. Menceloglu also had the opportunity to mentor bright undergraduate research assistants who contributed greatly to the research project, teach classes on perception and attention as a guest lecturer, and participate in community events to share scientific insights on human perception and cognition with the non-academic community.
